content: circle of the fae socks pattern by sophie skinner under the willow knits as a lover of fungi and a believer of all things magick i knew i wanted to create socks that encompass the mystical nature of the woods along with warm autumn tones since a young child i have always been captivated by fairy rings albeit a little wary… just in case a fairy ring is a circle of mushrooms that are shrouded in folklore and legend many believe they are a place where the fae folk congregate to play and dance legends warn against humans entering the ring joining the dance but these socks are completely safe to dance around in and perhaps they will even add a touch of fae energy and mischief to your every step if you make these socks i d love to see them tag me on instagram @underthewillowknits pg 1 pattern copyright sophie skinner 2022 for personal use only this pattern is knitted from the cuff down using the magic loop method on circular needles i have used size 2 5mm to achieve an adult size m although different needle sizes can be used to achieve your desired sized socks e g 2 25mm for a smaller size 2 75mm for larger all charts can be found on pg 6 although my colour work is shown using only one colour the charts are divided into 3 colours to help you clearly see the separate parts of the image this should make it a little easier if you wish to use different colours you will need… yarn 𓋼𓍊 sock weight/ fingering main colour mc approximately 80g contrast colour 1 cc1- heel cuff toe approximately 20 g contrast colour 2 cc2- colour work approximately 10g in my example shown i have used vesemir sock set by the fibre fox for mc and cc1 cuff/heel/toe and haar by nervus fibre for cc2 supplies 𓋼𓍊 2 5mm circular needles 𓋼𓍊 yarn needle for weaving in ends 𓋼𓍊 3 stitch markers abbreviations sts - stitches rs right side ws wrong side bor beginning of row k knit p pearl s1 slip 1 ssk slip slip knit slipped stitches together k2tog knit two stitches together p2tog pearl two stitches together inc1 increase by picking up one stitch in the bridge loop between two stitches insert left needle to pick up the bridge from back to front then knit the front of the picked up stitch pg 2 pattern copyright sophie skinner 2022 for personal use only instructions cuff 𓋼𓍊 using cc1 cast on 64 stitches i prefer to use the german twisted cast on as i find it a little stretchier join your round together being careful not to twist your stitches place a marker at the beginning of the row 𓋼𓍊 knit the cuff ribbing k1 p1 for a total of 12 row leg 𓋼𓍊 join mc and k for 4 row 𓋼𓍊 increase row *k8 inc1* 8 times you will now have 72 sts 𓋼𓍊
